title: Georgia House - Day 7 (2026-01-26)
summary:
Here is a structured markdown summary of the Georgia House session transcript:

## Overview
The session featured a prayer from Rabbi Joshua Heller, who provided a thoughtful message about courage, freedom, and the responsibility of legislators. No substantive legislation was discussed.

## Key Actions
None detected.

## Bills Introduced (First Reading)
- **HB 980**: Reconstituting the board of education of Early County
- **HB 981**: Authorizing the city of Cornelia, Georgia to exercise already defined powers

## Notable Moments
- Rabbi Joshua Heller delivered an inspiring prayer, drawing parallels between the Israelites' journey to the Promised Land and the challenges facing Georgia. He called on legislators to have the courage to "dive into deep swirling waters" and lead the state to a better future.
- The session opened with the Pledge of Allegiance.

## Votes
None recorded.

## Attendance
No quorum issues noted.

## Adjournment
The transcript does not specify when the session adjourned or the date of the next scheduled session.

you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you You you you you you you you you you you are allegiance to the flag of our country. Our chapel in this morning will be introduced by the gentleman from the 79th House District Representative Mike Wolensky. Representative Wolensky. Thank you speaker members of the House. Today I introduce Rabbi Joshua Heller. Rabbi Joshua Heller's in his 18th year as Senior Rabbi of Congregation of the Benetor and Sandy Springs. Under his 10 year Benetor has grown to be the third largest Jewish congregation in the whole state of Georgia. Rabbi Heller's congregants enjoy his caring, powerful, emotional sermons and he has an amazing sense of humor which always makes it very enjoyable. Rabbi Heller is a former president of the Atlanta Rebynical Association and is a member of the International Committee on Jewish Law and Standards. Rabbi Heller graduated from Harvard with a degree in computer science and passed on job offers from Silicon Valley to become a ninth generation rabbi. During the period after 9-11 he also served as the rabbi of the downtown synagogue in New York. One of the synagogues that's closest to the side of the World Trade Center. He and his wife Wendy are proud parents to three children to which born here in Georgia. I'm grateful and honored to call Rabbi Heller not only my Rabbi but a friend who I can always call for advice or help. Speaker Ralston, Honorable members of the house. I want to offer my profound gratitude for the opportunity to be with you today and in particular to thank Representative Wollensky for that gracious introduction. In our Jewish tradition as we read the book of Exodus we see it as our story and we read how the Israelites had been liberated from slavery in Egypt and they have witnessed ten horrific plagues and now they are free and heading towards the promised land not realizing that Pharaoh is close on their heels. They find themselves caught if you will between the devil and the deep red sea. There's a miracle the sea parts and the Israelites cross through joining together in a song of freedom. This is a story that I and members of my Jewish community hold dear and I hope that many of you do as well. I know what it means to have the pharaohs of many generations motivated by implacable hate stalking me through barren places and indeed one only needs to read the news of what happened in Texas just ten days ago to understand that that is not just an ancient story and I know that many of us here in Georgia understand the evil that was slavery and what it means for some of our brothers and sisters to be on a continued journey towards freedom and I would hope that all of us here understand what it means to be pilgrims on a journey to a better to a promised land and unfortunately all of us as Georgians understand what it means to live through a time of plagues and this is no plague of the first born the angel of death has not stopped with the old but sees as young as well and I pray that you join me in prayer and support for our medical professionals our first responders our educators and all the people whose simple honest work makes it possible for us to live our lives even as they are in harm's way because even as we see the light of dawn some of them have yet not yet emerged into light standing here today all Georgians know what it means to be caught between the pharaohs of our past forces that seek to take away cherished rights and freedoms and a deep sea ahead over which there seems to be no bridge in this moment of darkness turning to dawn of a sea about to part I would like to offer a word of hope to you our Jewish tradition a legend teaches us that as the Jews stood at the sea calling to God praying to God for help the prayers the supplications of Aaron the priest accomplished nothing the staff of Moses man of God had no effect created no path 12 tribes each sought their own route through raging waters it was only when one man not shown benamina dav stepped into the water not just up to his ankles not just to get his knees a little damp not just up to his chest or his neck not until the waters reached his nose his very soul no shown had the courage to dive in and the waters made a dry path for the Israelites to pass through what courage we must have my friends what courage must we have to leave behind pharaohs of our past what courage must we have must you have to have come here to have volunteered to service you leave homes and jobs and families and communities to serve the better the betterment of our state what courage we must have to leave behind the pharaohs of our past we must dive into deep swirling waters we must earn the right to celebrate on the other side when the Israelites finished crossing the sea they sang a song and it was a nation that sang a song not a song of unity but a song of harmony of call and response there is a great song of celebration that we have yet to sing but only if we cross and sing together let us pray members of the legislature I offer thanks for the service that each of you provide I pray that God grant wisdom to each of you I will not pray that you agree on all matters for that would surely be a false prayer but I do pray that you each come to see your work as holy you are guided by your faith your principles your integrity to bring a listening ear a caring heart a discerning soul and a mouth that speaks only truth I pray that you are able to seek the good of every resident of this state whether you see them as the least or the greatest and I pray that you are leaders are like our biblical hero not shown I do not ask that you walk on water but I ask that you lead us through it by example and make sure that each of us that every resident of our state every citizen every dweller is guided on a path to freedom and the promised land that God has promised each of us and let us say amen I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to Okay, that's going to be all we do in the local calendar today. We're moving on to morning orders. Morning orders. If you have a morning order, please come to the front. Morning orders will be limited to one minute per member. The chair recognizes representative, chairman Ken Trell from morning order. Thank you, Madam Speaker. Wow, loud. Hey, colleagues, it's way past time for Georgia to take a fresh look at how we educate our children. Even when public schools do an excellent job, there's always going to be a small percentage of students who do not perform well in a traditional classroom setting. This means we must focus on funding students, not systems, because one size does not fit all, especially when it comes to education. Should a family, should a low-income family be stuck in a chronically underperforming school? Should a student who's being bullied be forced to stay in a school where they can't learn? The answer is no. Yesterday, I introduced House Bill 999. This is school choice for all. School choice for all. Georgians want school choice. All the polling shows it. In fact, 77% of parents who send their kids to public school favor school choice. This is a bipartisan bill. It's sponsored by three Republicans and three Democrats so far. So I urge you to support school choice in Georgia this year. Thank you. The director recognizes Representative Setsler and the co-delegation for a morning order. Ladies and gentlemen, the House, I'd like to ask you to rise if you would please. We lost a friend of Cobb County yesterday. Colonel Michael H. Boyce, U.S. Marine Corps retired. The four-year chairman of Cobb County Board Commissioners passed away yesterday. He had served as the chair of Cobb County from 2000, being elected in 2016, served for four years and left office in early 2021. Chairman Boyce was born in California, 1949, graduated the University of Notre Dame in 1971, where on the tail end of the Vietnam War, he was commissioned as the second lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps. He served our country for 30 years, left active duty in 2001, and again, as a citizen, ran for office and was elected county chair in 2016. His wife, Judy, three kids, five grandkids, carry on Mike's heart in his tradition. He passed away yesterday after having suffered a first of many strokes about a week ago, was actually up in South Bend, Indiana, had been in a residential fellowship at the University of the University of the Leadership Mentor, in a graduate program there with his wife. It had a year there. It was really half of the time of his life mentoring young people. One of the ones to say about Chairman Boyce briefly is just the joyful spirit that he represented. As many of our military members are, they are able to be joyful even in hard times. I think those that know him recognize that in the face of the harshest criticism, he was always just such a friendly gentleman. Mike was a person in representing Cobb County that served people, looked after and cared people, cared for people, even they would never vote for him that didn't share his political philosophy, but just that kind of gentleman. That servant's heart just came through. Last thing I know Madam Chair, we were running it at a time. I will tell you though, just to give you a picture of the man, when he was running for office in 2016, he had had a mission trip scheduled to Romania. He was going to go for two weeks. He got through the primary, was in a primary runoff and that's six, eight week period between his primary and his primary runoff. We had a two week mission trip scheduled. He did the mission trip. He did cancel the mission trip because he had a political contest ahead of him. He focused on what was important in life. And I just want to celebrate him today and as we think about this young man that served, he was 72 years young, left us too soon, but we're proud of the time we had with him. We'd like to thank him and his family for the life he lived and I'd like to recognize us all recognizing the moment of silence. Thank you. Chair recognizes Representative Chocas for Morning Order. Thank you Madam Speaker. Good morning everyone. On your desk we've placed a book by Barry McCarthy. This is the book. It's titled Small Business Revolution. How Honors and Entrepreneurs can succeed. Mr McCarthy is the CEO of Deluxe Corporation. You know the Deluxe Corporation because it actually prints the checks that they use in our checking accounts. Most of you don't know that approximately 70% of their business deals with payment processing that Georgia accounts for over 80% of the payment processing business in the United States. Deluxe recently opened a facility in Georgia and created over 700 jobs. Mr McCarthy's book is listed as the number two best seller on the Wall Street Journal list of books. His company supports over four million small businesses annually. Mr McCarthy was a presenter at yesterday's Small Business Development Committee meeting. And thank you.
